questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient approaches the ophthalmologist complaining of severe pain in his right eye. He also complains of lacrimation and photophobia for several days. On examination, a descemetocele is seen on the cornea. The doctor advises the patient to avoid sneezing and coughing. If the patient sneezes, which of the following is not the sequelae?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Posterior capsular cataract Posterior capsular cataract is not a sequelae of corneal perforation. It is rare and occurs due to persistent hyaloid arteries.

Highyeild:

Perforation of corneal ulcer occurs when the ulcerative process deepens and reaches up to Descemet's membrane.This membrane is tough and bulges out as Descemetocele . At this stag e, any exertion on the part of patient, such as coughing, sneezin g, straining for stool, etc., will perforate the corneal ulcer. Sequelae of corneal perforation include: Prolapse of iris. Subluxation or anterior dislocation of lens Anterior capsular catarac t. Corneal fistula Purulent uveitis, endophthalmitis or even panophthalmilis may develop due to spread of irntraocular infection. Intraocular haemorrhage in the form of either vitreous haemorrhage or expulsive choroidal haemorrhage may occur in some patients due to sudden lowering of intraocular pressure.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Anterior capsular cataract A is one of the sequalae of descematocele. It forms when the lens comes in contact with an ulcer following perforation in the pupillary area. Option: B. Ectopia lentis is also one of the sequalae of descematocele. It occurs due to sudden stretching and rupture of zonules. Option: D. Prolapse of the iris is also one of the sequalae of descematocele. It occurs immediately following perforation in a bid to plug i t.

Extraedge:

Corneal perforation are ocular emergency with myriad causes such as Trauma Infection Autoimmune diseases loss of corneal innervation

questions.text: A 79-year-old male presented with a history of gradual progressive visual deterioration and disturbance in night and near vision (near acuity affected more than distance vision) along with a decrease in contrast sensitivity in brightly lit environments. On proper history, you notice the patient has been experiencing a myopic shift. On examination, decreased visual acuity and lens opacity were noted as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements are correct regarding the patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Occurrence of “lens within a lens phenomenon” is a common finding in such patients

options.label: B
options.text: Examination of lens position and integrity of the zonular fibers is not essential unless a history of trauma exists

options.label: C
options.text: Preoperative detection of retinal dystrophy does not affect the prognosis of the patient after definitive surgical management

options.label: D
options.text: Nutritional deficiencies have been established to play a significant role

questions.correct_answer: A. Occurrence of “lens within a lens phenomenon” is a common finding in such patients
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Occurrence of “lens within a lens phenomenon” is a common finding in such patients This is a classic case presentation of mature senile cataracts. A patient with senile cataract often presents with a history of gradual progressive deterioration and disturbance in vision. Decreased visual acuity is the most common complaint of patients with senile cataracts. Increased glare is another common complaint of patients with senile cataracts. This complaint may include an entire spectrum from a decrease in contrast sensitivity in brightly lit environments or disabling glare during the day to debilitating glare with oncoming headlights at night. At times, the nuclear changes are concentrated in the inner layers of the lens , resulting in a refractile area in the center of the lens, which often is seen best within the red reflex by retinoscopy or direct ophthalmoscopy. Such a phenomenon, which some call “lens within a lens phenomenon,” may lead to monocular diplopia that is not correctable with spectacles, prisms, or contact lenses.

Highyeild:

The progression of cataracts may frequently increase the dioptric power of the lens resulting in a mild-to-moderate degree of myopia or myopic shift. Consequently, presbyopic patients report an increase in their near vision and less need for reading glasses as they experience the so-called second sight. However, such occurrence is temporary, and, as the optical quality of the lens deteriorates, the second sight is eventually lost.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Slit lamp examination should not only concentrate on evaluating the lens opacity but the other ocular structures as well (eg, conjunctiva, cornea, iris, anterior chamber). Corneal thickness and the presence of corneal opacities , such as corneal guttate, must be checked carefully. The appearance of the lens must be noted meticulously before and after pupillary dilation. After dilation, nuclear size and brunettes as indicators of cataract density can be determined before phacoemulsification surgery. The lens position and integrity of the zonular fibers also should be checked because lens subluxation may indicate previous eye trauma, antecedent ocular surgery, metabolic disorders, or premature cataracts. Option: C. Optic nerve and retinal problems may account for the visual disturbance experienced by the patient. Furthermore, the prognosis after lens extraction is affected significantly by preoperative detection of pathologies in the posterior pole (eg, macular edema, retinal dystrophy, optic atrophy, severe glaucomatous cupping, age-related macular degeneration) and in the retinal periphery (eg, retinal breaks or extensive vitreoretinal traction). Option: D. The role of nutritional deficiencies in senile cataracts has not been proven or established. However, a high intake of the 18-carbon polyunsaturated fatty acids linoleic acid and linolenic acid reportedly may result in an increased risk of developing age-related nuclear opacity.

Extraedge:

Typically, myopic shift and second sight are not seen in cortical and posterior subcapsular cataracts. A cortical cataract generally is not clinically relevant until late in its progression when cortical spokes compromise the visual axis. The visual significance of oil droplet nuclear cataracts and small posterior subcapsular cataracts is evaluated best with a normal-sized pupil to determine if the visual axis is obscured.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Elschnig pearls Accumulation of clusters of proliferated epithelial cells. Particularly seen in post-operative cataract patients. Have the appearance of a bunch of grapes or soap bubbles. May migrate to the posterior capsule , continue to accumulate, and cause significantly decreased vision

questions.text: Identify the type of cataract shown in the Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Morgagnian cataract A Jordanian cataract is a hyper mature cataract in which the total liquefaction of the cortex has allowed the nucleus to sink inferiorly. A Jordanian cataract is a form of premature cataract formed by liquefaction of the cortex and sinking of the dense nucleus to the bottom of the capsular bag. Appears that a morganite cataract is a special form of cortical-nuclear cataract . It is assumed that the process of fiber dissolution which is encountered in cortical cataracts in general is speeded up and occurs en masse in morgagnian cataracts

Highyeild:

Histopathologically, accumulation of eosinophilic fluid between lens cells with displacement and degeneration of bordering cells characterize cortical cataracts. Spherical droplets or globules of released protein from the breakdown of cortical cell walls are called morgagnian globules. These globules may accumulate and may eventually replace the entire cortex and result in a mature morgagnian cataract.

Extraedge:

The central dense nucleus at this point would become gravity dependent, often displaced inferiorly to the lower equatorial region of the lens within the capsular bag.

Symptoms include gradually worsening muscle loss and weakness Muscles often contract and are unable to relax. Other symptoms may include cataracts, intellectual disability, and heart conduction problems. In men, there may be early balding and an inability to have children.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of seeing colored halos. There are no complaints of pain or redness in the eye. The eye is irrigated and the Fincham test is done. The halos split up when a stenotic slit is passed across the pupil. What is the treatment of choice for a given condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgical removal of Lens and IOL implantation

questions.correct_answer: A. Surgical removal of Lens and IOL implantation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Surgical removal of Lens and IOL implantation The patient is most likely suffering from cataracts. Colored halos are seen in cases of acute purulent conjunctivitis, cataract, and glaucoma. They're seen in acute purulent conjunctivitis due to the prismatic effect of mucus flakes present on the cornea. They're washed away by eye irrigation. Fincham stenotic slit test is used to differentiate between colored halos of cataracts and glaucoma. As the slit is moved across the pupil halos split and revolve in case of cataracts while in case of angle closure glaucoma, they do not split.

Highyeild:

Halos occur in cataracts due to the breaking of white light into a coloured spectrum due to the presence of water droplets in the lens. They're seen in glaucoma due to the accumulation of fluid in the corneal epithelium and due to alterations in the refractive condition of the corneal lamellar.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Typical antibiotics - Not preferred in the given case. Option: C . Keratoplasty - A cornea transplant (keratoplasty) is a surgical procedure to replace part of your cornea with corneal tissue from a donor. Your cornea is the transparent, dome-shaped surface of your eye. It's where light enters your eye and is a large part of your eye's ability to see clearly. Option: D . Peripheral laser iridotomy- Laser peripheral iridotomy (LPI) is indicated to prevent or overcome a suspected relative pupillary block by creating an alternative pathway for aqueous flow.

Extraedge:

Keratoplasty is used in case of corneal abnormalities, it is of no use in colored halos.

questions.text: The Government of India as a part of a public health initiative found out that aging is the most common cause of cataracts. Which of the following is the most common form of senile cataract?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cuneiform Cataract A) Cuneiform cataract(70%) B) Cupuliform cataract(5%) C) Nuclear cataract(25%) It is characterized by wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between. These extend from the equator towards the center and in early stages can only be demonstrated after dilatation of the pupil They are first seen in the lower nasal quadrant. These opacities are present both in the anterior and posterior cortex and their apices slowly progress toward the pupil

Highyeild:

On oblique illumination, these present a typical radial spoke-like pattern of greyish-white opacities (). On distant direct ophthalmoscopy , these opacities appear as dark lines against the red fundal glow. Since the cuneiform cataract starts at the periphery and extends centrally, the visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage.

questions.text: Sheena comes to OPD with her daughter. It was found that her daughter has an inborn error of metabolism called Lowe’s syndrome. What will be the ophthalmic findings in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Congenital Cataract, Glaucoma, Blue Sclera
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital Cataract, Glaucoma, Blue Sclera Lowe's (Oculo-cerebral-renal) syndrome is a rare inborn error of amino acid metabolism. Ocular features include congenital cataracts, glaucoma, and blue sclera. Systemic features of this syndrome are mental retardation, dwarfism, osteomalacia, muscular hypotonia, and frontal prominence.

questions.text: Meenamma,58 years old is a diabetic lady. Her sugars are poorly controlled. She has a hazy vision. What type of cataract will be characteristically noted in her eyes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Snowflake cataract Diabetes is associated with two types of cataracts: Senile cataract in diabetic and progresses rapidly. appears at an early age True diabetic cataract. The classical diabetic cataract is also called 'snowflake cataracts or 'snowstorm cataracts '. It is a rare condition, usually occurring in young adults due to osmotic overhydration of the lens.

Highyeild:

Osmotic overhydration of the lens occurs due to the accumulation of sorbitol , when glucose is metabolized by NADPH+-dependent aldose reductase. Initially, a large number of fluid vacuoles appear underneath the anterior and posterior capsules, which is soon followed by the appearance of bilateral snowflake-like white opacities in the cortex. Such opacities may resolve spontaneously or mature within a few days.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Sunflower cataract Option C. Polychromatic lusture Option: B. Breadcrumb cataract- Cataracts in patients with uveitis occur due to an imbalance in the intraocular milieu and may have a characteristic morphological appearance, described in literature as breadcrumb appearance (polychromatic luster).

questions.text: Irappa, a 55-year-old man presents with an inability to see objects in bright light. On examination, she is diagnosed with cataracts. Where is the characteristic finding not seen?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cuneiform cataract Cuneiform senile cortical cataract. It is characterized by wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between. These extend from the equator towards the center and in early stages can only be demonstrated after dilatation of the pupil. They are first seen in the lower nasal quadrant.

Highyeild:

These opacities are present both in the anterior and posterior cortex and their apices slowly progress towards the pupil. On oblique illumination, these present a typical radial spoke-like pattern of greyish-white opacities. On distant direct ophthalmoscopy, these opacities appear as dark lines against the red fundal glow.

Extraedge:

Since the cuneiform cataract starts at the periphery and extends centrally, the visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage.

questions.text: Ramesh had blunt eye trauma. he visited ophthalmology OPD. The findings are seen in the eye as shown in the image below. What is the type of cataract seen?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Early Rosette Cataract Discrete subepithelial opacities are of most common occurrence.

Highyeild:

Early rosette cataract (punctate). It is the most typical form of concussion cataract. It appears as feathery lines of opacities along the star-shaped suture lines; usually in the posterior cortex. Late rosette cataract . It develops in the posterior cortex 1 to 2 years after the injury. Its sutural extensions are shorter and more compact than the early rosette cataract.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B - Traumatic zonular cataract . It may also occur in some cases, though rarely. Diffuse (total) concussion cataract. It is of frequent occurrence. A concussion cataract may occur due to blunt trauma. Option: D . Blue dot cataract - Cerulean cataracts, also known as blue dot cataracts, are developmental cataracts characterized by blue and white opacifications scattered in the nucleus and cortex of the lens. Patients with cerulean cataracts are usually asymptomatic until 18-24 months of age and often do not need them removed before adulthood

questions.text: The most common cause for this clinical sign is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cataract A cataract is the clouding of the lens or any opacity within the lens which leads to a decrease in vision and loss of sight if left untreated. There are three primary types of cataracts: Nuclear sclerotic cortical posterior subcapsular.

Highyeild:

Clinical features of cataract Symptoms. One of the earliest visual disturbances with the cataract is glare or intolerance of bright light Uniocular polyopia (i.e., doubling or trebling of objects). It is also one of the early symptoms. It occurs due to irregular refraction by the lens Coloured halos . This is due to the breaking of white light into a colored spectrum due to the presence of water droplets in the lens. Black spots in front of eyes. Image blur, distortion of Images, and misty vision. Deterioration of vision. It is painless and gradually progressive.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Patients with central opacities (e.g., cupuliform cataract i.e. Posterior subcapsular cataract) have early loss of vision. These patients see better when the pupil is dilated due to dim light in the evening (day blindness). Option: C. In patients with peripheral opacities (e.g., cuneiform cataract) visual loss is delayed and the vision improves in bright light when the pupil is contracted. Option: D . In patients with nuclear sclerosis , distant vision deteriorates due to progressive index myopia. Such patients may be able to read without presbyopic glasses. This improvement in near vision is referred to as ‘second sight’.

Extraedge:

SIGNS: Visual acuity testing. Depending upon the location and maturation of the cataract, the visual acuity may range from 6/9 to just PL + Oblique illumination examination. It reveals the color of the lens in the papillary area which varies in different types of cataracts Test for iris shadow . When an oblique beam of light is thrown on the pupil, a crescentic shadow of the pupillary margin of the iris will be formed on the greyish opacity of the lens, as long as a clear cortex is present between the opacity and the pupillary margin When the lens is completely transparent or opaque, no iris shadow is formed. Hence, the presence of an iris shadow is a sign of immature cataracts. Distant direct ophthalmoscopic examination- A reddish-yellow fundal glow is observed in the absence of any opacity in the media. A partial cataractous lens shows a black shadow against the red glow in the area of the The complete cataractous lens does not even reveal the red glow Slit lamp examination to assess site, size, color, and hardness of the lens
